name: Unity
help: Unity is usually launched by double-clicking its icon from the desktop. However, it is also possible to run it from the command line (from the macOS Terminal or the Windows Command Prompt). When launched in this way, Unity can receive commands and information on startup, which can be very useful for test suites, automated builds and other production tasks.

properties.name: BatchMode
properties.help: Run Unity in batch mode. This should always be used in conjunction with the other command line arguments, because it ensures no pop-up windows appear and eliminates the need for any human intervention. When an exception occurs during execution of the script code, the Asset server updates fail, or other operations that fail, Unity immediately exits with return code 1.Note that in batch mode, Unity sends a minimal version of its log output to the console. However, the Log Files still contain the full log information. Opening a project in batch mode while the Editor has the same project open is not supported; only a single instance of Unity can run at a time.

properties.name: BuildLinux32Player
properties.help: Build a 32-bit standalone Linux player (for example, <c>-buildLinux32Player path/to/your/build</c>).

properties.name: BuildLinux64Player
properties.help: Build a 64-bit standalone Linux player (for example, <c>-buildLinux64Player path/to/your/build</c>).

properties.name: BuildLinuxUniversalPlayer
properties.help: Build a combined 32-bit and 64-bit standalone Linux player (for example, <c>-buildLinuxUniversalPlayer path/to/your/build</c>).

properties.name: BuildOSXPlayer
properties.help: Build a 32-bit standalone Mac OSX player (for example, <c>-buildOSXPlayer path/to/your/build.app</c>).

properties.name: BuildOSX64Player
properties.help: Build a 64-bit standalone Mac OSX player (for example, <c>-buildOSX64Player path/to/your/build.app</c>).

properties.name: BuildOSXUniversalPlayer
properties.help: Build a combined 32-bit and 64-bit standalone Mac OSX player (for example, <c>-buildOSXUniversalPlayer path/to/your/build.app</c>).

properties.name: BuildWindowsPlayer
properties.help: Build a 32-bit standalone Windows player (for example, <c>-buildWindowsPlayer path/to/your/build.exe</c>).

properties.name: BuildWindows64Player
properties.help: Build a 64-bit standalone Windows player (for example, <c>-buildWindows64Player path/to/your/build.exe</c>).

properties.name: EditorTestsResultFile
properties.help: Path where the result file should be placed. If the path is a folder, a default file name is used. If not specified, the results are placed in the project's root folder.

properties.name: TestPlatform
properties.help: The platform you want to run tests on.

properties.name: StableExitCodes
properties.help: Define Unity exit codes which don't let the build fail.

properties.name: FullConsoleLog
properties.help: Show full editor log in console output.

properties.name: RunEditorTests
properties.help: Run Editor tests from the project. This argument requires the <c>-projectPath</c>, and it's good practice to run it with <c>-batchmode</c> argument. <c>-quit</c> is not required, because the Editor automatically closes down after the run is finished.

properties.name: ReturnLicense
properties.help: Return the currently active license to the license server. Please allow a few seconds before the license file is removed, because Unity needs to communicate with the license server.

properties.name: Quit
properties.help: Quit the Unity Editor after other commands have finished executing. Note that this can cause error messages to be hidden (however, they still appear in the Editor.log file).

properties.name: Serial
properties.help: Activate Unity with the specified serial key. It is good practice to pass the -batchmode and -quit arguments as well, in order to quit Unity when done, if using this for automated activation of Unity. Please allow a few seconds before the license file is created, because Unity needs to communicate with the license server. Make sure that license file folder exists, and has appropriate permissions before running Unity with this argument. If activation fails, see the Editor.log for info.

properties.name: ExecuteMethod
properties.help: Execute the static method as soon as Unity is started, the project is open and after the optional Asset server update has been performed. This can be used to do tasks such as continous integration, performing Unit Tests, making builds or preparing data. To return an error from the command line process, either throw an exception which causes Unity to exit with return code 1, or call EditorApplication.Exit with a non-zero return code.To use ExecuteMethod, you need to place the enclosing script in an Editor folder. The method to be executed must be defined as static.

properties.name: ExportPackage
properties.help: Export a package, given a path (or set of given paths). In this example <c>exportAssetPath</c> is a folder (relative to to the Unity project root) to export from the Unity project, and <c>exportFileName</c> is the package name. Currently, this option only exports whole folders at a time. This command normally needs to be used with the <c>-projectPath</c> argument.

properties.name: CustomArguments
properties.help: Custom parameters. To pass parameters, add them to the command line and retrieve them inside the function using <c>System.Environment.GetCommandLineArgs</c>.

properties.name: CreateProject
properties.help: Create an empty project at the given path.

properties.name: LogFile
properties.help: Specify where the Editor or Windows/Linux/OSX standalone log file are written.

properties.name: ForceD3d9
properties.help: (Windows only) Make the Editor use Direct3D 9 for rendering. Normally the graphics API depends on player settings (typically defaults to D3D11).

properties.name: ForceD3d11
properties.help: (Windows only) Make the Editor use Direct3D 11 for rendering. Normally the graphics API depends on player settings (typically defaults to D3D11).

properties.name: ForceGLCore
properties.help: (Windows only) Make the Editor use OpenGL 3/4 core profile for rendering. The Editor tries to use the best OpenGL version available and all OpenGL extensions exposed by the OpenGL drivers. If the platform isn't supported, Direct3D is used.

properties.name: ForceGLCoreXY
properties.help: (Windows only) Similar to <c>-force-glcore</c>, but requests a specific OpenGL context version.

properties.name: ForceGLES
properties.help: (Windows only) Make the Editor use OpenGL for Embedded Systems for rendering. The Editor tries to use the best OpenGL ES version available, and all OpenGL ES extensions exposed by the OpenGL drivers.

properties.name: ForceGLESXY
properties.help: (Windows only) Similar to <c>-force-gles</c>, but requests a specific OpenGL ES context version.

properties.name: ForceClamped
properties.help: (Windows only) Used with <c>-force-glcoreXY</c> to prevent checking for additional OpenGL extensions, allowing it to run between platforms with the same code paths.

properties.name: ForceFree
properties.help: Make the Editor run as if there is a free Unity license on the machine, even if a Unity Pro license is installed.

properties.name: ImportPackage
properties.help: Import the given package. No import dialog is shown.

properties.name: NoGraphics
properties.help: When running in batch mode, do not initialize the graphics device at all. This makes it possible to run your automated workflows on machines that don't even have a GPU (automated workflows only work when you have a window in focus, otherwise you can't send simulated input commands). Please note that <c>-nographics</c> does not allow you to bake GI on OSX, since Enlighten requires GPU acceleration.

properties.name: SilentCrashes
properties.help: Don't display a crash dialog.

properties.name: ProjectPath
properties.help: Specify the path of the unity project.

properties.name: AssetServerUpdate
properties.help: Force an update of the project in the Asset Server given by IP:port. The port is optional, and if not given it is assumed to be the standard one (10733). It is advisable to use this command in conjunction with the -projectPath argument to ensure you are working with the correct project. If no project name is given, then the last project opened by Unity is used. If no project exists at the path given by -projectPath, then one is created automatically.

properties.name: BuildTarget
properties.help: Allows the selection of an active build target before a project is loaded.

properties.name: CleanedLogFile
properties.help: Detailed debugging feature. StackTraceLogging allows features to be controlled to allow detailed logging. All settings allow None, Script Only and Full to be selected.

properties.name: UserName
properties.help: Enter a username into the log-in form during activation of the Unity Editor.

properties.name: Password
properties.help: The password of the user, required when launching.

properties.name: EditorTestsCategories
properties.help: Filter editor tests by categories.

properties.name: EditorTestsFilter
properties.help: Filter editor tests by names.

properties.name: ExportPaths
properties.help: Export a package, given a path (or set of given paths. Currently, this option only exports whole folders at a time. This command normally needs to be used with the <c>-projectPath</c> argument.

properties.name: ExportPackageFile
properties.help: The path where the package should be created. This command normally needs to be used with the <c>ExportPaths</c> argument.
